title: Intel's Struggles and TSMC’s 3nm Advantage
description: In this episode, we dive into the ongoing challenges Intel faces in securing advanced semiconductor manufacturing with TSMC, the impact on their strategic roadmap, and the fierce competition over TSMC's limited 3nm capacity.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Hello and welcome to another episode of 'Life is Artificial,' where we explore the cutting edge of technology, innovation, and what the future could look like.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Today, we're focusing on a hot topic from the semiconductor industry: Intel’s struggles to secure manufacturing capacity for its next-generation chips with Taiwan's TSMC, or Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company. There's a lot to unpack here, so let’s dive in.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: The source for today’s story comes from a recent article by Digitimes titled *Pat Gelsinger 傳11月來台見魏哲家 台積取消英特爾折扣傳言太荒唐*.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Now, if you've been following the semiconductor industry, you know that Intel, once the unrivaled leader, has been facing some serious headwinds in recent years. One of Intel’s biggest challenges has been maintaining its own manufacturing roadmap, particularly in comparison to companies like TSMC, which has been consistently advancing in process technology.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Intel has been planning to use TSMC’s 3nm process for some of its upcoming processors, like the Lunar Lake and Arrow Lake series. But here's the issue: TSMC’s 3nm production capacity is extremely limited, with Apple, TSMC’s longstanding partner, taking up a large portion of it for its own chips.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Initially, Intel was hoping to secure a significant discount from TSMC—reportedly up to 40%—to make this collaboration feasible financially. However, industry insiders are dismissing this idea as ‘unrealistic.’ They point out that TSMC's advanced nodes, especially 3nm, are in such high demand that there's no need for the company to offer Intel, or any customer, a discount on what is essentially premium real estate in chip manufacturing.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: For context, TSMC’s 3nm production, particularly the N3B and newer N3E processes, is already a battleground for major tech players. Not only is Apple utilizing these nodes, but Qualcomm, NVIDIA, and even Samsung have shown interest. In fact, competition is so fierce that Intel had to agree to pay a premium just to ensure timely access to TSMC’s 3nm nodes.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: This situation has brought Intel into a rather difficult position. Intel’s CEO, Pat Gelsinger, is reportedly planning a visit to Taiwan in November to meet with TSMC’s Chairman, Mark Liu, to discuss their future cooperation. The aim of this meeting could likely be to negotiate costs, secure TSMC’s capacity for Intel’s 3nm requirements, and potentially look ahead to TSMC’s upcoming 2nm process.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: So why is Intel so keen on TSMC’s 3nm nodes? It boils down to Intel’s ambitions to remain competitive. Intel’s own internal manufacturing, especially its 20A and 18A nodes, has faced delays and yield issues. As a result, Intel has been forced to outsource a portion of its production to TSMC. Products like Intel’s upcoming Lunar Lake processors, which rely on TSMC’s N3B node, are pivotal for Intel to stay competitive in the high-performance computing market.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: The challenges don’t end here. Intel also has its sights set on the AI GPU market with its planned Falcon Shores project, which is expected to need TSMC’s 3nm or even 2nm capacity by 2025. The project will likely use TSMC’s advanced CoWoS, or Chip-on-Wafer-on-Substrate, packaging technology, making the competition for TSMC's capacity even more intense.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Intel is essentially in a race against time to secure enough of TSMC’s 3nm capacity for its current roadmap while trying to catch up with its own manufacturing setbacks. For TSMC, Intel’s demand for 3nm manufacturing means they need to carefully manage capacity to avoid affecting their other high-profile clients like Apple, who are equally dependent on TSMC’s advanced nodes.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: And then there’s the cost factor. TSMC’s 3nm pricing is estimated to be around $20,000 per wafer, making it one of the most expensive processes TSMC has ever produced. Given this, any hopes Intel might have for a substantial discount seem far-fetched at best. Most of TSMC’s discounts are reserved for long-term partners who’ve been part of the development process for these advanced nodes, such as Apple.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: In short, the relationship between Intel and TSMC is complicated. While Intel needs TSMC to keep up with its roadmap, TSMC has little incentive to offer Intel discounts or special treatment over its other clients. This is especially true considering that Intel is both a customer and a competitor.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: We’ll be watching closely as this story develops, particularly as Pat Gelsinger’s upcoming meeting with Mark Liu could set the tone for Intel and TSMC’s relationship moving forward. Will Intel be able to secure the manufacturing power it needs at an affordable cost, or will it face even higher production expenses? Only time will tell.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: That’s it for today’s episode. If you want to learn more about this topic, I highly recommend checking out the original article on Digitimes. You can find the link in the description.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Thank you for tuning in to ‘Life is Artificial.’ Until next time, keep exploring the future of technology, and remember, the path forward is paved with innovation, resilience, and sometimes, a little bit of drama in the tech world. Take care!
